Hi everyone,

Is there an induction principle in Mathlib that is a generalization of the following Nat.twoStepLeInduction from The Mechanics of Proof for k steps?

Or a way I can simulate it?

Thanks a lot!
Unless I am missing something, this can only be used starting from 0 no?
In particular the Le in the name means that the base can be arbitrary.
I thought about it a bit more, the version I had in mind is probably more trouble than it's worth. Sorry about that and thanks!
Xavier Généreux has marked this topic as resolved.
Hi David, I was looking for n steps from any starting points k.

Usually the easy way to do this is to just use the equation compiler: instead of trying to find the exact induction principle you need in the library, you just make a recursive call to the lemma you're proving, and supply the decreasing_by and termination_by fields if they turn out to be needed.

Or define a recursive function foo (of arbitrary result type, could be Unit) that makes the case splits and recursive calls you want in your induction principle, and then use foo.induct (and ignore the function).
I recommend proving k \le n -> P n by strong induction on n.
